articles.title: 5 Mistakes Companies Make Defining Material Controls
articles.author: Zia Rezvi ACMA CGMA
articles.excerpt: Drawing from 16 months of FTSE 100 implementation experience, this article identifies the five most common mistakes companies make when defining material controls—and how to avoid them. From bottom-up control inventories that produce 150+ controls to vague materiality criteria that create scope ambiguity, learn the practical lessons that separate successful implementations from struggling ones.
keyTakeaways: Mistake #1: Starting bottom-up instead of top-down from principal risks
Mistake #2: Vague materiality criteria that lead to scope creep
Mistake #3: Confusing 'important' with 'material'
Mistake #4: Delayed board engagement
Mistake #5: Copying peer company control lists without applying your own materiality

articles.title: Why the 2025 Dry Run is Non-Negotiable
articles.author: Zia Rezvi ACMA CGMA
articles.excerpt: Companies that skip or skimp on the H2 2025 dry run consistently struggle in FY2026. This article makes the case for why a genuine 6-8 week stress-test is not optional, drawing on real examples of dry runs that uncovered critical issues before they became board-level problems. Learn what a good dry run looks like and how to sell it to your CFO.
keyTakeaways: Dry runs typically uncover 10-15 issues that would have surfaced in FY2026
Board confidence is built through seeing the process work, not through presentations
GRC platform validation is critical—dry run is the first real-world test
Companies that conduct dry runs are 3x more likely to declare effectiveness confidently
Cost of dry run (£20k-£50k) is negligible compared to risk of FY2026 failure

articles.title: Board Communication Strategies for Provision 29
articles.author: Zia Rezvi ACMA CGMA
articles.excerpt: How do you engage a busy board on a complex technical topic like Provision 29? This article provides a complete toolkit for board communication, from the initial Q1 2025 workshop to quarterly dashboard reviews. Includes sample board packs, effective questions directors should be asking, and red flags that indicate board disengagement.
keyTakeaways: Start with a 2-hour board workshop in Q1 2025—make it interactive, not a lecture
Use 'Approach on a Page' dashboards—boards don't want 50-slide decks
Focus on 'so what?'—what does this mean for strategy and stakeholders?
Encourage challenge—good boards ask tough questions
Make it a standing full board agenda item, not just Audit Committee

articles.title: Integrating Provision 29 with SOX 404: A Dual-Listed Company's Guide
articles.author: Zia Rezvi ACMA CGMA
articles.excerpt: If you're dual-listed (US and UK), you're sitting on a goldmine: your existing SOX 404 framework. This article shows how to leverage SOX for P29 efficiency, where to expand scope, and how to create a unified control library. Includes a gap analysis template and case study from a FTSE 100/S&P 500 company that reduced P29 implementation effort by 40%.
keyTakeaways: Financial reporting controls: ~80-90% SOX/P29 overlap
Expand P29 scope to operational, cyber, ESG controls not in SOX
Create unified control library with SOX/P29 tags
Use SOX testing results as P29 evidence where applicable
Enhance SOX dashboards for full board (P29 requires board visibility)

articles.title: Provision 29 and ESG: The Emerging Control Domain
articles.author: Zia Rezvi ACMA CGMA
articles.excerpt: ESG and sustainability reporting controls are rapidly becoming material. With mandatory climate disclosures (TCFD, SDR) and increasing investor scrutiny, boards can no longer ignore ESG data quality. This article explores how to assess ESG controls for P29 materiality, provides examples from early adopters, and looks ahead to 'material controls in waiting' like AI governance.
keyTakeaways: 68% of FTSE companies now include ESG controls in their MCI
Common ESG material controls: Scope 1/2/3 emissions calculation, ESG data aggregation, third-party data validation
ESG control failures can be material: Greenwashing accusations, regulatory penalties, investor backlash
Emerging 'material controls in waiting': AI governance, climate scenario analysis
ESG controls require specialist expertise—don't delegate to Finance alone

caseStudies.title: FTSE 100 Retailer: 16-Month Journey to P29 Compliance
caseStudies.summary: Large UK retailer with £30bn+ revenue and complex operations (retail, logistics, property) successfully implemented Provision 29 in 16 months. Started in Q4 2023, conducted dry run in Q2 2025, and is on track for confident declaration in 2027 annual report.
approach: Strong board engagement from day 1 (CEO/CFO championship)
Leveraged existing SOX controls for financial reporting
Expanded scope to operational (Health & Safety, Supply Chain) and ESG (Modern Slavery, Carbon Reporting)
Conducted rigorous 8-week dry run in Q2 2025
lessonsLearned: Top-down approach prevented scope creep—started with 40 controls, refined to 25 truly material ones
Board workshop in Month 1 was critical—created urgency and secured resources
Dry run uncovered 12 issues—all remediated before FY2026 start
Operational controls (H&S, Supply Chain) required more effort than anticipated—often informal and undocumented
Control owner workshops were essential—1st line needed training and context
results: Board expressed high confidence after dry run review
On track for 'full effectiveness' declaration in 2027
GRC platform now used for BAU risk management beyond P29
Cultural shift: Increased accountability and control awareness across organisation

keyMetrics.resourceUtilisation: 3-5 FTE throughout; peaked at 8 FTE during dry run

caseStudies.title: FTSE 250 Industrial: Rapid 12-Month Implementation
caseStudies.summary: Mid-cap manufacturing company with strong existing control environment (ISO 9001, 14001, 27001) completed compressed 12-month P29 implementation. Started in Q1 2024, leveraged existing frameworks, and conducted dry run in Q4 2024.
approach: Leveraged existing ISO 27001 (cyber), ISO 9001 (quality), ISO 14001 (environmental) frameworks
Conducted gap analysis: Identified 42 material controls (20 from existing ISO, 22 new)
Used existing control documentation formats—adapted for P29
Built on existing risk management platform—added P29 module
Compressed Phases 1-2 to 8 months due to strong foundation
lessonsLearned: Gap: Financial reporting controls were less mature than operational controls—required more effort
Board initially disengaged—treated as 'compliance project'—mid-course correction needed
Compressed timeline was ambitious but achievable due to existing infrastructure
Control owner engagement critical—held 3 workshops across sites
results: Dry run successful with only 3 minor issues identified
Board confidence built through quarterly deep-dives
Unified control framework across ISO and P29

phaseBreakdown.phase1: 2 months (accelerated due to existing risk register)

caseStudies.title: Listed Financial Services Firm: Leveraging SOX 404
caseStudies.summary: Dual-listed financial services firm (UK and US) with mature SOX 404 programme leveraged existing framework for P29. 80% of material controls were already SOX controls; expanded scope to regulatory compliance, AML, and cyber resilience.
approach: Started with SOX 404 control population (90 controls)
Applied P29 materiality criteria—identified 65 material controls (55 SOX + 10 new)
New controls: AML transaction monitoring, regulatory compliance (FCA), cyber incident response
Used existing SOX platform—added P29 tagging and reporting
Leveraged SOX testing results for P29 evidence
lessonsLearned: Board education needed: P29 is broader than SOX—not just financial controls
Regulatory controls (FCA, AML) required specialist input—not covered by SOX
SOX management certification vs P29 board declaration—different governance level
Unified board dashboard combining SOX and P29 was highly effective
results: Seamless integration of SOX and P29—single control library
Board receives quarterly unified dashboard (SOX + P29)
Dry run leveraged SOX Q3 testing—efficient and audit-ready
Positioned for 'full effectiveness' declaration with high confidence

keyMetrics.resourceUtilisation: 2 FTE dedicated + shared SOX team resources

videos.description: A concise video introduction to Provision 29, covering: What changed from the 2018 Code, why it matters, timeline for compliance, and what the board needs to do in the next 6 months. Perfect for board workshops or executive briefings.

videos.title: How to Define Materiality Criteria (Practical Workshop)
videos.description: A practical, step-by-step guide to defining materiality criteria for material controls. Covers quantitative thresholds, qualitative factors, decision tree creation, and common pitfalls. Includes worked examples from different sectors (retail, financial services, industrial).
keyTopics: Quantitative thresholds: £X million, Y% of profit, regulatory penalty
Qualitative factors: Strategic importance, reputational impact, stakeholder significance
Common mistake: Setting thresholds too low (results in 100+ controls)
Real examples: How FTSE companies set their thresholds

videos.title: Running a Control Documentation Workshop
videos.description: How to run an effective workshop with control owners (1st Line) to document material controls, assign ownership, and define effectiveness criteria. Includes facilitation tips, sample agendas, and real examples of well-documented vs poorly-documented controls.
keyTopics: How to explain 'what is a material control?' to operational managers
Documenting: What, How, When, By Whom
Common pushback and how to address it

videos.title: Preparing for Your Board Declaration: A Year-End Checklist
videos.description: As you approach the end of FY2026, what do you need to have in place to support the board's declaration? This video provides a comprehensive year-end checklist, sample board packs, and guidance on drafting declaration language for effectiveness, partial effectiveness, or ineffectiveness scenarios.
keyTopics: Quarterly board reviews: Were they substantive?
Board confidence assessment: Is the board ready to declare?
Annual report disclosure: What to include
